title: Generating good unique ids in Go
Description: Survey of 7 libraries for generating good, unique ids in Go.

inline_content.Text: Description: Survey of 7 libraries for generating good, unique ids in Go.

title: Each note needs a unique id.

inline_content.Text: Each note needs a unique id.

title: Generating unique ids is easy if you can coordinate.

inline_content.Text: Generating unique ids is easy if you can coordinate.

title: The simplest way is to get database to do it: use
AUTOINCREMENT
c
column and the database will generate unique id when you insert a new
note
c
row into a table.

inline_content.Text: The simplest way is to get database to do it: use
column and the database will generate unique id when you insert a new

title: For example, you want the app to also generate unique note id when offline, when it cannot talk to the database.

inline_content.Text: For example, you want the app to also generate unique note id when offline, when it cannot talk to the database.

title: The requirement of non-coordinated generation of unique ids comes up often in distributed systems.

inline_content.Text: The requirement of non-coordinated generation of unique ids comes up often in distributed systems.

title: A simple solution is to generate a random id. If you give it 16 bytes of randomness, the chances of generating the same random number are non-existent.

inline_content.Text: A simple solution is to generate a random id. If you give it 16 bytes of randomness, the chances of generating the same random number are non-existent.

title: It’s such a common problem that over 30 years ago we created a standard for this called
UUID/GUID
a
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universally_unique_identifier

inline_content.Text: It’s such a common problem that over 30 years ago we created a standard for this called

title: We can do better than GUID. A good random unique id:

inline_content.Text: We can do better than GUID. A good random unique id:

title: is unique; we can’t skip the basics

inline_content.Text: is unique; we can’t skip the basics

title: can be sorted by its string representation

inline_content.Text: can be sorted by its string representation

title: is time-clustered i.e. ids generated at the same time are close to each other when sorted

inline_content.Text: is time-clustered i.e. ids generated at the same time are close to each other when sorted

title: string representation can be used as part of URL without escaping

Bvbb: 4 bytes of time (seconds) + 3 byte machine id + 2 byte process id + 3 bytes random

Bvbb: ~6 bytes of time (10 ms) + 1 byte sequence + 2 bytes machine id

title: How to generate unique ids using different libraries:

inline_content.Text: How to generate unique ids using different libraries:

title: oklog/ulid
c
allows custom entropy (randomness) source but pays for that with complex API.

inline_content.Text: allows custom entropy (randomness) source but pays for that with complex API.

title: sony/sonyflake
c
is the smallest but also the least random. It’s based on Twitter’s design for generating IDs for tweets.

inline_content.Text: is the smallest but also the least random. It’s based on Twitter’s design for generating IDs for tweets.

title: For simplicity the example code serializes
sony/snoflake
c
in base16. It would be even shorter in base62 encoding used by other libraries, but other libraries provide that out-of-the-box and for
sony/snoflake
c
I would have to implement it myself.
